S3.T1.caption: Table 1:  Model configurations of the Learn2Diss models. The base versions of HuBERT ( Hsu et al. ( 2021 )  or wavLM ( Chen et al. ( 2022 ) ) are used for feature extractor and frame-level encoder initialization. All models use  L = 6 𝐿 6 L=6  ECAPA-TDNN layers. L2D corresponds to Learn2Diss, H stands for HuBERT and W stands for wavLM.
references: Following the prior works of Baevski et al. (2020); Hsu et al. (2021), we use 960960960 hours of the Librispeech dataset Panayotov et al. (2015) to train the models111The code for Learn2Diss pre-training along with the model checkpoints used for the results in this work will be released upon acceptance.. For the frame-level encoder, we use the base version of the HuBERT (Hsu et al. (2021)) or wavLM (Chen et al. (2022)) model with 121212 encoder layers and an embedding dimension of d=768𝑑768d=768. The utterance-level feature encoder is designed with dl=1024,l=1..L−1d^{l}=1024,l=1..L-1 having the ECAPA-TDNN architecture (Desplanques et al. (2020)) with output dimension of dL=256superscript𝑑𝐿256d^{L}=256. The utterance-level model is initialized with ECAPA-TDNN model pre-trained with the InfoNCE SimCLR (Chen et al. (2020)) loss. The model configurations explored in this work are given in Table 1. The variational network consists of P=2𝑃2P=2 neural layers to predict the mean and variance of the variational distribution. The mean and variance networks are made of 222 feed-forward layers with input dimension of 256256256, hidden dimension of 204820482048 and output dimension of 768768768.

S3.T2.caption: Table 2:  Results on various tasks of SUPERB ( Yang et al. ( 2021 ) ) benchmark. Semantic tasks are phoneme recognition (PR), automatic speech recognition (ASR), keyword spotting (KS), intent classification (IC), and slot filling (SF), while non-semantic tasks are speaker identification (SID), automatic speaker verification (ASV) and emotion recognition (ER). The metrics used are accuracy (Acc % percent \% ), phoneme error rate (PER % percent \% ), word error rate (WER % percent \% ), F1 score (F1 % percent \% ), concept error rate (CER % percent \% ) and equal error rate (EER % percent \% ). The proposed model configurations are described in Table  1 . The best result in each task is  bolded  and second best is  underlined . Results with  ✤  are not given in the reference and are generated with the publicly available model checkpoint.
references: We demonstrate the effectiveness of representations from proposed models using a battery of tasks proposed in Speech Processing Universal PERformance Benchmark (SUPERB Yang et al. (2021)). The pre-trained model is the frozen embedding extractor. For each downstream task, a weighted sum of layer representations from the embedding extractor is generated and these aggregated features are input to light-weight prediction heads. Only the weights in the layer-wise pooling and the prediction head parameters are fine-tuned on the downstream tasks. Table 2 reports the results for various baseline systems as well as the proposed models.

S4.T3.caption: Table 3:  ABX error rate ( % percent \% ) for various systems reported on ZeroSpeech2021 ( Dunbar et al. ( 2021 ) ) challenge dataset. The proposed model configurations are described in Table  1 . Best result is  bolded  and second best is  underlined .
references:
The results are reported in Table 3.
For these experiments, we have extracted the representations from last layer of the frame-level encoder. The HuBERT based Learn2Diss encoder models achieves the best results in this task. The L2D-H6 model shows an average relative improvement of 25.95%percent25.9525.95\% over it’s parent model (HuBERT Hsu et al. (2021)).

S4.T4.caption: Table 4:  Word Error Rate (WER % percent \% ) on test set of Librispeech ( Panayotov et al. ( 2015 ) ) corpus. Only models with base size ( 12 12 12  layers of transformer encoders with embedding dimension of  768 768 768 ) are considered. The proposed model configurations are described in Table  1 . Best results in each setup is  bolded  and second best is  underlined . Results with  ✤  are not reported in the cited reference and are generated using the pre-trained checkpoints available publicly.
references:
Following the ASR setup discussed in the prior works,  Baevski et al. (2020); Hsu et al. (2021); Chen et al. (2022); Baevski et al. (2023), we fine-tune only the transformer layers of the frame-level encoder using connectionist temporal classification loss (CTC) (Graves et al. (2006)) loss. The CTC target vocabulary includes 262626 English alphabets, space token, blank symbol and an apostrophe. The models are evaluated using 111 hour or 101010 hours of labeled data from LibriLight (Kahn et al. (2020)) or using 100100100 hours from Librispeech data (Panayotov et al. (2015)). The Torch-audio ASR toolbox333https://github.com/pytorch/audio/tree/main/examples/hubert is used to perform the fine-tuning with all the hyper-parameters set to default. The CTC decoding is done using the Librispeech official 444-gram language model. The word error rates (WER%percent\%) are reported on the "clean" and "other" splits of test set of Librispeech (Panayotov et al. (2015)) corpus in Table 4.
The results demonstrate that proposed L2D approach achieves state-of-the-art (SOTA) results or similar to previous SOTA for all the settings. In particular, it is seen that the improvements for the proposed models over the parent models are consistent even when the model is fine-tuned with 100100100 hours of supervised data.
Similar trends are also seen on the development set of Librispeech, which are reported in Appendix A.2.

S4.T5.caption: Table 5:  Effect of disentanglement using mutual information (MI) minimization on SUPERB ( Yang et al. ( 2021 ) ) benchmark. The proposed model configurations are described in Table  1 . Without the disentanglement using MI loss, the configuration reverts to continued pre-training of the frame-level and utterance-level encoders in an isolated fashion.
references:
These results are evaluated on the SUPERB (Yang et al. (2021)) benchmark settings. Results in Table 5 show that mutual information module leads to better enrichment of semantic components of frame-level encoder while degrading the non-semantic (content) information.
In particular, for the L2D-W12 configuration, it is observed that the ASR WER is improved relatively by 19.319.319.3% using the disentanglement loss on the frame-level encoder. Additionally, without the MI objective, the frame-level encoder can contain substantial speaker information (SID accuracy of 79.4779.4779.47%). A significant drop in speaker identification accuracy is observed (797979% →→\rightarrow 313131%) when the disentanglement objective is introduced.

A1.T6.caption: Table 6:  Effect of hidden representation aggregation for mutual information module. Downstream tasks are evaluated following SUPERB Yang et al. [ 2021 ]  benchmark setting. Lower(Higher) values of phoneme error rate(PER % percent \% ), word error rate(WER % percent \% ), Accuracy for given tasks is preferred for  Frame-level ( Utterance-level  encoder)
references: Results reported in Table 6 on the various downstream tasks in SUPERB challenge show an average relative improvement of 11.26%percent11.2611.26\% for frame-level encoder tasks and an average relative improvement of 15.53%percent15.5315.53\% for utterance-level encoder tasks for the aggregate representations. The reason for the improvement could be the fact that disentanglement of information in internal representations and the final representations jointly maybe more realistic compared to achieving the same goal with only the final layer representations.

A1.T7.caption: Table 7:  Word Error Rate (WER % percent \% ) on dev set of Librispeech Panayotov et al. [ 2015 ]  corpus. Only models with BASE sized ( 12 12 12  layers of transformer encoders with embedding dimension of  768 768 768 ) transformers pre-trained on  960 960 960  hours of LibriSpeech are considered. Best results in each setup is  bolded  and second best is  underlined . Results with  ✤  are not reported in the cited reference, but generated using the publicly released checkpoint of these models.
references: We report in Table 7 the ASR results for 333 different setups followed in prior works by Baevski et al. [2020], Hsu et al. [2021], Chen et al. [2022] using 111 hour / 101010 hour split from LibriLight (Kahn et al. [2020]) or 100100100 hours from LibriSpeechPanayotov et al. [2015]. Word error rates (WER%percent\%) are reported on the "clean" and "other" splits of development set of LibriSpeech corpus.

A1.T8.caption: Table 8:  Phone and Speaker purity averaged over "clean", "other" splits of test set of Librispeech Panayotov et al. [ 2015 ]  corpus. Best result is  bolded  and second best result is  underlined
references:
Phone purity measures the homogeneity of phonemes within clusters. It can be interpreted as frame-level phone accuracy, if each of the frame-level discrete targets (k𝑘k-means clusters) is associated with a unique phoneme label. A higher purity indicates better quality of representing unique phoneme label with the given representation. For the models in Table 8, frame level representations from the final layer are quantized into 204820482048 clusters using k-means algorithm. The k-means clustering is trained on LibriSpeech(100100100h) (Panayotov et al. [2015]) subset.
Once the clustering is performed, the clusters are compared with the frame-level phonetic targets (available through ASR force-alignment Panayotov et al. [2015]).
